head_templates.name: ja-adj
head_templates.expansion: 楽(たの)しい • (tanoshii) -i (adverbial 楽(たの)しく (tanoshiku))

forms.form: たのしくなかったです

args.formal_negative_past: く なかった です

etymology_text:
⟨tano₁siki₁⟩ → */tanʷosikʲi/ → /tanoshii/
From Old Japanese. First attested in the Kojiki of 712 CE. No Ryukyuan cognates exist; as a result, further derivation unknown. Theories include:
* A compound of 手 (ta, “hand”, combining form) + 伸す (nosu, “to extend”)
*: This is problematic, as nosu has first been attested starting from the early 900s, with no A/B distinction (see Jōdai Tokushu Kanazukai for details).
* From 田神 (tano, literally “rice paddy god”)
*: No reading of 神 (*no, “god”) exists.
* A borrowing from an unknown language
*: No words resemble *tanV meaning "fun" or "to enjoy".

examples.text: 好きな食べ物は？ アイスクリームです。
examples.roman: Suki na tabemono wa? Aisu kurīmu desu.
examples.translation: What's your favorite food? - It's ice cream.
examples.english: What's your favorite food? - It's ice cream.

examples.text: 君が好きだからこそこれほど頑張っているんだよ。
examples.roman: Kimi ga suki da kara koso kore hodo ganbatte iru n da yo.
examples.translation: It's precisely because I like you [because of my fondness for you] that I'm working this hard.
examples.english: It's precisely because I like you [because of my fondness for you] that I'm working this hard.

examples.translation: “I like you.” → idiomatically used to express: “I love you.”
examples.english: “I like you.” → idiomatically used to express: “I love you.”

examples.text: どうとも好きにしなさい。
examples.roman: Dō to mo suki ni shinasai.
examples.translation: Feel free to do as you like.
examples.english: Feel free to do as you like.

etymology_text:
The 連(れん)用(よう)形(けい) (ren'yōkei, “stem or continuative form”) of the verb 好(す)く (suku, “to like, to be fond of, to enjoy, to feel love for”).
First cited to the late 900s in the 宇津保物語 (Utsubo Monogatari).

examples.text: 狸 兼名苑云狸［音𨤲和名太奴木］摶鳥為粮者也
examples.english: Raccoon dog: According to Jian Ming Yuan (兼名苑), raccoon dogs [read as 𨤲 (ri), native Japanese 太奴木 (tanuki)] always prey on birds.
examples.translation: Raccoon dog: According to Jian Ming Yuan (兼名苑), raccoon dogs [read as 𨤲 (ri), native Japanese 太奴木 (tanuki)] always prey on birds.

examples.ref: 2020 March 21, Kazuki Nakashima, “Rabbit Town”, in BNA ビー・エヌ・エー [BNA], episode 2, spoken by Shirou Ogami (Yoshimasa Hosoya), Toho/Netflix:
examples.english: If you're a raccoon, you'd have stripes on your tail. No matter how you look at it, you're a raccoon dog.
examples.translation: If you're a raccoon, you'd have stripes on your tail. No matter how you look at it, you're a raccoon dog.
examples.text: アライグマなら尻尾にシマがある。どう見でもタヌキだ。
examples.roman: Araiguma nara shippo ni shima ga aru. Dō mi demo tanuki da.

categories: Requests for transliteration of Japanese quotations

examples.roman: yai yai, soko na tanuki me

raw_glosses: (figurative) a person who pretends to be good but in fact is cunning (compare English sly fox)
glosses: a person who pretends to be good but in fact is cunning (compare English sly fox)

alt_of.extra: (tanuki-udon) and 狸蕎麦 (tanuki-soba): styles of various noodle dishes

examples.text: 狸を決め込む ― tanuki o kimekomu ― pretend to be a raccoon dog → feign sleep

raw_glosses: (rare) short for 狸寝入り (tanuki neiri): pretending to be asleep
glosses: short for 狸寝入り (tanuki neiri): pretending to be asleep

raw_glosses: (rare, obsolete) short for 狸汁 (tanuki-jiru): a soup made from tanuki meat mixed with daikon, burdock root, etc.
glosses: short for 狸汁 (tanuki-jiru): a soup made from tanuki meat mixed with daikon, burdock root, etc.

etymology_text: According to one theory, derived from 手貫 (tanuki, “arm glove, gauntlet”), which raccoon dog hide was sometimes used for.

examples.translation: A car is running. / Cars are running.

glosses: to move forward; (of a machine) to operate, function; (of objects) to move at a high speed (of a vehicle)

examples.translation: Don't forget your stance and give in to emotions.
examples.english: Don't forget your stance and give in to emotions.

glosses: to give over oneself to; to commit oneself to (usually something bad)
to spread out, scatter, splatter, spout
to lead or extend in a certain direction

args.1: おなか が すいた

head_templates.expansion: お腹(なか)が空(す)いた • (onaka ga suita)

etymology_text: The perfective form of お腹が空く (onaka ga suku, “to become hungry”, literally “one's stomach becomes empty”).
